100 [[war elephant]]s |casualties1=Few |casualties2=15,000-20,000 {{Harv|Davis|1999|pp=181, 183, 184 183}} }} {{Campaignbox Babur}} The '''First Battle of Panipat''', on 21 April 1526, was fought between the invading forces of [[Babur]] and the [[Lodi dynasty|Lodi Empire]]. It took place in north India and marked the beginning of the [[Mughal Empire]]. This was one of the earliest battles involving [[gunpowder warfare|gunpowder firearms]] and [[field artillery]] in India.Butalia, Romesh C. ''The Evolution of the Artillery in India: From the Battle of Plassey to the Revolt of 1857'', (Allied Publishing Limited, 1998), p. 16. [[File:Vaki'at-i Baburi - The Battle of Panipat (1526) by Deo Gujarati.jpg|thumb|right|The battle of Panipat between the armies of Babur and Ibrahim Lodi (1526). Babur was invited by Daulat Khan Lodi to enter India and defeat Ibrahim Lodi.Chandra, Satish. ''Medieval India: From Sultanat to the Mughals'', Vol. 2, (Har-Anand, 2009), pp. 27-31. An illustration to the Vaqi 'at-i Baburi, by Deo Gujarati, c.1590]] == Background == After losing [[Samarkand]] for the third time, [[Babur]] gave attention to conquer [[India]] as he reached the banks of the [[Chenab river|Chenab]] in 1519.{{cite book|author1=VD Mahajan|title=History of medieval India (10th ed.)|publisher=S. Chand|isbn=8121903645|page=429}} Until 1524, his aim was to only expand his rule to [[Punjab region|Punjab]], mainly to fulfil his ancestor Timur's legacy, since it used to be part of his empire.{{sfn|Eraly|2007|p=27–29}} At the time parts of north India were under the rule of [[Ibrahim Lodi]] of the [[Lodi dynasty]], but the empire was crumbling and there were many defectors. He received invitations from Daulat Khan Lodi, Governor of Punjab and Ala-ud-Din, uncle of Ibrahim.{{cite book|last=Chaurasia|first=Radhey Shyam|title=History of medieval India : from 1000 A.D. to 1707 A.D.|year=2002|publisher=Atlantic Publ.|location=New Delhi|isbn=8126901233|pages=89–90}} He sent an ambassador to Ibrahim, claiming himself the rightful heir to the throne of the country, however the ambassador was detained at Lahore and released months later.{{cite book|author1=VD Mahajan|title=History of medieval India (10th ed.)|publisher=S Chand|isbn=8121903645|page=429}} Babur started for Lahore, Punjab, in 1524 but found that Daulat Khan Lodi had been driven out by forces sent by Ibrahim Lodi.{{sfn|Chandra|2007|p=27}} When Babur arrived at Lahore, the Lodi army marched out and his army was routed.{{sfn|Chandra|2007|p=27}} In response, Babur burned Lahore for two days, then marched to Dipalpur, placing Alam Khan, another rebel uncle of Lodi's, as governor.{{sfn|Chandra|2007|p=27}} Alam Khan was quickly overthrown and fled to Kabul. In response, Babur supplied Alam Khan with troops who later joined up with Daulat Khan Lodi and together with about 30,000 troops, they besieged Ibrahim Lodi at Delhi.{{sfn|Chandra|2007|p=28}} He defeated them and drove off Alam's army and Babur realized Lodi would not allow him to occupy the Punjab.{{sfn|Chandra|2007|p=28}} ==Battle== Hearing of the size of Ibrahim's army, Babur secured his right flank against the city of Panipat, while digging a trench covered with tree branches to secure his left flank. In the center, he placed 700 carts tied together with ropes. Between every two carts there were breastworks for his matchlockmen. Babur also ensured there was enough space for his cavalry to charge between these carts. When Ibrahim's army arrived, he found the approach to Babur's army too narrow to attack. While Ibrahim redeployed his forces to allow for the narrower front, Babur quickly took advantage of the situation to flank (''tulghuma'') the Lodi army. Many of Ibrahim's troops, were unable to get into action and as the battle turned against Ibrahim, they fled.Watts, Tim J. "Battles of Panipat". In Mikaberidze, Alexander (ed.) ''[[Conflict and Conquest in the Islamic World: A Historical Encyclopedia]]'', (ABC-CLIO, 2011), p. 707. Faced with [[musket]] fire, cannon fire and cavalry attacks from all sides, Ibrahim Lodi fought and died with 6,000 of his remaining troops. ===Advantage of cannons in the battle=== Babur's guns proved decisive in battle, firstly because Ibrahim Lodi lacked any field artillery, but also because the sound of the cannon frightened Lodi's elephants, causing them to trample Lodi's own men. ===Tactics=== {{unreferenced section|date=April 2014}} [[File:Babur introduced field guns at panipat, 1526.jpg|thumb|left|Babur introduced field guns at Panipat, 1526]] New tactics introduced by Babur were the ''tulghuma'' and the ''araba''. ''Tulghuma'' meant dividing the whole army into various units, viz. the Left, the Right and the Centre. The Left and Right divisions were further subdivided into Forward and Rear divisions. Through this a small army could be used to surround the enemy from all sides. The Centre Forward division was then provided with carts (''araba'') which were placed in rows facing the enemy and tied to each other with animal hide ropes. Behind them were placed cannons protected and supported by mantlets which could be used to easily maneuver the cannons. These two tactics made Babur's artillery lethal. The cannons could be fired without any fear of being hit, as they were shielded by the bullock carts held in place by hide ropes. The heavy cannons could also be easily traversed onto new targets, as they could be maneuvered by the mantlets which were on wheels. ==Aftermath== Ibrahim Lodi died on the field of battle along with 15,000 of his troops. Vikramajit, ruler of Gwaliyar, was killed as well. The battle of Panipat was militarily a decisive victory. Politically it gained Babur little, and initiated a new phase of his establishment of the Mughal empire. ==See also== * [[Second Battle of Panipat]] * [[Third Battle of Panipat]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== *{{Citation |first=Paul K. |last=Davis |year=1999 |title=100 Decisive Battles: From Ancient Times to the Present |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=1-57607-075-1 }} * {{cite book|title= Medieval India: From Sultanat to the Mughals Part - II| ISBN=9788124110669|author=Satish Chandra|publisher=Har-Anand Publications}} {{Mughal Empire}} {{Pashtun nationalism}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Battle of Panipat (1526)}} [[Category:Battles involving the Indian kingdoms|Panipat 1st Battle 1526]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1526]] [[Category:Battles involving the Mughal Empire|Panipat 1526]] [[Category:Lodhi dynasty]] [[Category:Panipat]] [[Category:History of Haryana]] [[Category:1526 in India]]
